_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Central Farm Service 

233 West Ciro Street

PO Box 68

Truman, MN 56088

Risk Management Plan - EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at the Facility:



The Coop board, management and employees at Central Farm Service, Mankato, MN location, are committed to the prevention of accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.  



2. Facility Information and Regulated Substances Handled: 



The primary activity at the facility is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored and handled for direct application. Anhydrous ammonia is used for crop production nutrients. The facility has 1-45,000 gallon storage tank; and additional available capacity of approximately 20,000 gallons in nurse tanks when the nurse tanks are on site during the spring planting and fall harvest seasons. The maximum quantity handled at one time would be a tank truck holding 40,000-45,000 pounds.



3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:



The facility has implemented Minnesota Dept. of Agriculture Rules and Regulations, the Standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia; and 40 CFR part 68 as they apply to this facility. The facility equipment was installed in 2015 by an outside contractor who worked with the Minnesota Department of Agriculture to ensure full compliance of all rules and regulations.  Internal semi-annual inspections of all bulk and nurse tank equipment are conducted, including inspection of load and unload equipment, with any needed maintenance being done as part of those inspections. Visual checks are to be conducted daily at

the facility.



4. The Five-year Accident History:



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have:

a) Caused any death, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or

b) Resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or

environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program:



The facility and/or facility personnel:

a) Has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38 and 40 CFR 68.95. The plan includes a response plan regarding anhydrous ammonia releases and what to do in the event of a release. Emergency action plan and response training is discussed at employee annual training sessions, including training every July relative to overall emergency planning and response. 

b) Undergoes anhydrous ammonia training, including emergency response training every fall.  

c) Has an Incident Response Plan as required per Minnesota Statutes and Rules. 

d) Has provided state and local authorities the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

c) Has coordinated and works with local emergency responders; 

d) Has a Safety Data Sheet for anhydrous ammonia as part of their emergency response plan for quick access and reference.

e) Has a Minnesota AWAIR (A Workplace Accident and Injury Reduction) program in place and is committed to a safe working environment as well as protection of the community and environment in which we operate.





6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Safety improvement and review of the covered process is on-going at the facility.  However, there are no current planned or pending site improvements at this time.
